author: mjtravaille

description.text:
In ancient times, contraptions known as water clocks were used as one of the earliest methods of tracking time. These methods have seldom been used after the invention of the pendulum clock in the 16th century. With this timer, we make use of this exceedingly old concept and make it new again with 3D printing!  
This model makes use of only 3 printed parts and result in a fully functional water drop timer. As you could have guessed by the name, the timer (as well as its ancient counterpart) work by having a constant dripping of water from a reservoir. This water will then fall into a balanced arm with coins acting as counterweights, with a little time the arm will balance out; signifying the end of the timed period.   
By altering the amount and type of coins in the counterbalance, we can calibrate the timer for different amounts of time.   
In addition, mounting holes for a standard 5mm LED (or a piezo buzzer) have been included in the design. Using contacts on the bottom of the balancing arm and on the motion stop (the square-looking piece on the legs of the device, this stops the movement of the balance arm at 90 degrees), you can complete a circuit that will power the indicators.   
Continue to the instruction tab to find out how to make your very own timer.  
NOTE: The image you see of the Legs above is not what yours will look like, this was the result of poor 3D Print that broke after removal from the print bed. Yours will be complete and will have 2 additional mounting holes.

----------------------Items Required----------------------
  • 13/32" or 1mm drill bit (Optional, read on for clarification)
  • M3 Bolt x 10-30mm (Optional, read on for clarification)
  • Coins, multiple types and quantities
    • ----------------------Assembly/Construction---------------------- To begin the construction of this device you will print out all of the pieces, here are a few things you should know...
  • Print out the "Balance_Arm_rev1" and "Main_Water_Tank_rev1" with 100% infill, this will take longer than it would with only partial infill but it will ensure that there are no leaks
  • You can print these using either PLA or ABS, both of these plastics are not soluble in water
    • If you are not able to print the rather small "Pin" (as I was) you can use an M3 bolt in its place, any length will do (preferably longer than 10mm). If you find that the small hole at the bottom of the Main Water Bucket is not clear and/or perfectly round, use the 13/32 or 1mm drill bit to clear it out. Once you have printed all of the parts you can move on to assembly....
  • Slide the Balance Arm onto the shaft protruding from the Legs of the timer, they should go on easily and have no friction when rotated
  • Insert the pin (or M3 bolt) into the hole on the shaft where the balancing arm lies, this will ensure that the arm does not slide off
  • Slide the Main Water Bucket onto the top of the legs, they should also go on smoothly without any interference
    • Optionally, you can use the 4 mounting holes made available on the platform of Legs to bolt the device onto a larger piece of wood, plastic, etc. However, if have found that this was not necessary, even with a fully filled Main Water Tank. At this point, if you chose so, you can attach the LED or piezo buzzer onto the included mount (the small right-most platform extended from the legs). ----------------------Usage---------------------- To use your Water Drop Timer, follow the below instructions....
  • Place the type and quantity of coins required for your timing duration on the small bucket on the Balance Arm (refer to table below)
  • Fill the Main Water Bucket with water, plugging the hole at the bottom
  • Unplug the hole on the Main Water Tank when you are ready to begin the timing duration
  • Wait until the Balancing Arm levels out, at which point your timing duration is complete
    • To know how many and which coins must be used to get different timing duration's, refer to the table below.... NOTE: The table makes an approximation between Canadian and American currency weights, the difference should not affect your outcomes too adversely. 2 Quarters: 25 seconds
    4 Quarters: 50 seconds
    6 Quarters: 1 minute 15 seconds
    Loonie (Canada only): 10 seconds
    Toonie (Canada only): 12 seconds
    4 Nickles: 45 seconds
    6 Nickles: 1 minute 10 seconds
    8 Nickles: 2 minutes
    4 Penny/Dime: 5 seconds You can use combinations of these coin combinations to reach a custom time period, although they may not be as accurate. ----------------------Calibration (Optional)---------------------- If you calibrate the timer yourself, you will be likely get a more accurate reading from the timer. Since the more scientific method of using the timer this will take too long to calculate each time, we simply measure the approximate timings. Follow the below instructions....
  • Gather the different combinations of coins (or more) that are listed in the above Usage area
  • Place the each combination of coins in the smaller bucket on the Balance Arm (one combination at a time)
  • Plugging the hole at the bottom of the Main Water Bucket, fill the bucket with water
  • Unblocking the hole, start a different timer and wait until the Balance arm levels out
  • Record the amount of time this took
    • Repeat the above process for each of the combinations of coins, recording each. In the end you will have a precisely calibrated list of different coin combinations and their respective times.

title: Ukulele Hanger- winged
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a lovely winged uke hanger for your wall. The holes are roughly the size of a standard drywall screw and that's what I used to mount it. I think ukes are light enough not to bother with anything more substantial, but it's your call.

There are two versions. One has buttresses behind the horns to support printing without added supports. I've printed both with & without supports and they both are functional. The buttresses seem to keep the back of the horns clean. I painted them with acetone to bond the layers and dress it up a bit. My printer settings for this were:
0.4mm nozzle
0.3mm layer height
3 perimeters
40% infill
3mm brim Hung with drywall screws but you could use other anchors depending on your wall and confidence.

description.text:
A.M.E.E. is a military robot from the science fiction thriller Red
Planet where it guides a team landing on planet mars. To beam A.M.E.E. from the virtual pixel matrix into the real world
it was necessary to modify all the parts e.g. add pins, replace
the gears, etc.
Followed by solving many troubles to get the right distances
between the parts and to prevent lock up of the moving bars. Based on CAD design available on Grabcad
https://grabcad.com/library/animal-running-1 The silver version is a control print with the uploaded STL files
using PLA 25% fill density, 2 layer shell, 0.1mm layer height and
70% print speed in ~30 hours. Assembly time ~1,5 hours. The timing for the motion profile can be set as you like. High resolution image links

title: GT2 Belt cutting and glueing helper tool

description.text:
If you are in the situation to make your own endless GT2 belt, e.g. for a belt extruder, you could order that endless belt ready to use or you could make use of spares and remainders in your toolbox to make your own one.  
This tool is intended to help you producing your own GT2 belt with cyanoacrylate or superglue. As the internal structure of the belt is not contiguous in this setup, the belt will not stand heavy loads.  
See instructions how to produce your own endless belt.

Insert end of belt into the holder, so that it covers the full cutting edge and it fits in the toothed bed. Use a tool like a screwdriver to make sure it fits tight. Use a blade of a cutter to shorten it. Then measure needed belt length on one of either side of the belt and insert into the tool appropriately. This means, if you are measuring on the longer side (top of the belt tip) insert the belt in such a way, that the exact length is reached at the top tip side. Do not change direction!
If you inserted the belt from the right, forward to the left and measure accordingly. Remove the remaining belt from the tool and move the belt end in the tool some millimeters to the left or right, just that the end is not atop of the cutting line and fix it in the tool again. Apply superglue or cyanoacrylate to the first cut surface, making sure no glue comes to the toothed side, and insert it accordingly into the tool. Use a screwdriver or something similar to fix it and "rub" the belt towards the other end, so that some pressure is applied on the cut area. Apply some glue to the backside, so that it could soak into openings between the two belts. Wait for the adhesive to dry and remove the ready belt. Be careful with the amount of glue!
Cyanoacrylate reacts with PLA and you do not want to fix your belt with the tool. Make sure your glue is only applied to the belt and not to areas in contact with the tool. Take personal security precautions!
Wear gloves and personal security equipment to make sure no adhesive or glue could touch tissue, eyes mouth and any other pieces of body. Use common sense! No guarantees or responsibilities taken
You work on your own risk with tools and chemicals that impose severe risk to your own and other peoples health and safety. The belt is uncertified, not to be used in sensitive or protection areas
The resulting belt is only for personal use. It is not certified for any security relevant machinery or use cases.

title: Living Memorial to the Holocaust at the Museum of Jewish Heritage

description.text: The Living Memorial to the Holocaust at Museum of Jewish Heritage in Battery Park City in Manhattan, New York CIty honors those who died in the Holocaust, and stands to educate its visitors about 20th and 21st century Jewish history and heritage. The Museum opened in 1997 and contains items about modern Jewish history and the Holocaust. The six-sided building with a six-tiered pyramidal roof is symbolic of the six points of the Star of David, which is also detailed on the top of the roof, and the six million Jews who perished in the Holocaust. Click here to learn more about this project: http://www.turnerconstruction.com/experience/project/6E2D/living-memorial-to-the-holocaust-at-the-museum-of-jewish-heritage

description.text:
The Monette Socket is an experimental component that is under development to be part of a prosthesis and is currently being tested for upper limb prostheses. It is heat formed from a 3D printed part. By heat forming it, a simple dimensional sized 3D printed shape creates a socket that is customized to fit the user. During the thermoforming, there is cross bonding of the linearly extruded PLA as it is further annealed to create a much stronger bond between layers of the printed part. This socket uses a 1/2 inch - 20 thread flange locknut. This nut will allow the socket to be screwed onto a conventional prosthetic terminal device. The nut in the pictures can be obtained from McMaster Carr.... http://www.mcmaster.com/#94831a671/=wbk3jh In the included pictures, this socket is formed over a plaster mold of an amputee's residual limb. The socket design also lends itself to molding over other cast or printed models of the residual limb. This socket is designed for a trans-radial amputee and was trimmed and buffed with a Dremel to allow for freedom of elbow motion of the residual limb. Below is a link to a video of a Monette Socket being heat formed...
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2n0LvtSFq18&feature=youtu.be This device was co-designed with Skip Meetze. Special thanks to the RIT e-NABLE team and other volunteers in the www.enablingthefuture.org community. Thanks to Harrision Ham and Joe Hoppes and staff, Advanced Orthopedics and Prosthetics in Newport Richey, FL for addition designs of the Monette socket.

Normally, a printer can replicate itself, I tried to make a printer that would produce itself! I mixed structure and mechanics Its strenghts are ease of assembly and maintenance, starting from basic components you can put all together in 3 hours and in some minutes you can enter and replace ever part the essential structure is therefore solid and movements are driven by linear actuators of 80 mm its movements can reach 300 mm/second and for me it works best from 60 to 80 mm following pla/pet, wood, bronze
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IzVVqruGan4 extruder (0.40 hole with filament of 1.75) is totally nude and allows not only to check any problems but also to rectify during printing plate 40x30(Z20) does not require regulation, it allows remote preparation and cleaning, I made some printing trials, of various size and duration, among the most interesting the one s where I printed all stress texts and “Robotica” at life-size http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:614366 in the last two weeks I printed 300 hours non-stop (I paused 2/3 minutes just to change filament and coil) with printings of about 5, 15, 40 and 60 hours ... I published along with pictures and videos also stl files for plastic parts this printer whose commercial name will be Qubit is part of a project leading to printing center service promoted by Fly-Image Technologies sagl in the next months but in agreement with partners the printer is free for non commercial use to publish here all the data about the project would require a great deal, then I apologize if I do not publish a technical project (that I am not able to do) and a complete list of components (yet to be finalized) but I am at your disposal at this address [email protected] if any of you want to make one of this printer, you can write to me and I can explain all I know and is needed I've been inspired by freebot (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:570718) printbot (http://printrbot.com/shop/assembled-s...) la ormerod 2 (https://reprappro.com/shop/reprap-kit...) funbot (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:560343) Bukito (https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/...) I created this low profile knob for the Reprapdiscount smart controller because the other knobs on Thingiverse were too tall for the installation and the rotary switch hole was not precise enough to prevent the knobs from falling off.  
This knob is very basic in design. Feel free to adjust the SCAD file (included) to make the knob the perfect height that you require.  
The low profile knob really helps to make traversing the menu of the smart controller more accurate.

Print the knob in PLA with 20% infill and 0.2mm layer height.  
Ensure that your hot end is clean to prevent any PLA blobs from forming in the rotary switch hole. This will ensure that the knob fits perfect on the LCD smart controller without the need for trimming.  
The low profile knob really helps to make traversing the menu of the smart controller more accurate.   
Enjoy!

title: Mostly Printed CNC 525 MPCNC "C-23.5mm OD"
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Changelog
5/9/17 - New XYZ Part to allow for T8 Leadscrew driven Z axis.
7/13/16 - New Roller Assemblies. No more motor mount flex, less hardware needed. More, mostly printed! New size added.
5/25/16 - New Center and Z Axis assemblies, More rigid!, easier to square, universal tool mount.
4/24/16 - New Corner assembly, easier to square, shorter print time, more rigid. Mostly Printed CNC / MultiTool
These parts are for 23.5mm OD conduit.
25mm OD here-http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:790533
25.4mm OD here- http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1671517 WE WON! Grand Prize winner!. Thank You all for the votes and cooperation. Nice write up, explains this in more detail Here I set out to build a minimal cost CNC Machine with the goal of some basic aluminum capabilities and easily swap out the functionality. More info
https://www.vicious1.com/ Hardware and printed parts available here.
https://vicious1-com.myshopify.com/ Printing info
https://www.vicious1.com/blog/parts/ The only special tools needed are a hacksaw, and a drill to for 4 holes. This can be easily expanded to almost any length, width, and depth depending on rigidity required. Shorter lengths = more rigid. This is built using hardware store emt conduit (In the US it is sold as 3/4" (ID)), or as an upgrade you can use stainless steel tubing. Most woods and plastics should be no problem. I milled Aluminum with a footprint of 23.5in x 32in x 4in. Aluminum works well https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GIYMuYgX0rY You can switch the spindle out with a drag knife, laser, Extruder, ect, making it a great prototyping multi-tool. By adding length and depth It could easily be used to shape large easily milled things like wood, foam, or plastics. Keep it small for aluminum.

I am using marlin / Ramps 1.4, there are a lot of options if you don't like this combo, grbl, tiny g, ect. The X and Y steppers are wired in parallel, just like the z axis is on a 3d printer. Now that I have it together Im having some strange things happen with Estlcam, and was wondering if someone can help me out. I am trying to carve out a basic wood sign (about 2mm letter depth) as a test. I am importing my svg file into Estlcam from Inkscape and creating toolpaths using the engrave tool, my settings are set up like those on Allted's site as well. I save the CNC Program and put it into my machine via SD (using Full LCD only, no Repetier, Pronterface, etc) Before I start the machine I set it to where I want the origin to be (X, Y, and Z) then turn the machine on I goto Print from SD and here is where the fun begins.... The toolhead moves approx 6 inches in X and 6 in Y away from my origin and then starts the carve/engrave. The Z is a little funky to, but Im not sure its the same type of issue (somehting tells me its tool settings or something). Also the engraving/carve is backwards on the workpiece, I found a way to get around this by flipping the drawing in Estlcam, but I would prefer to not have to do this if possible. Thank you in advance, Im going to put this in the forum as well in case anyone else runs into problems (easier to find on there)

comments.text: Can I use A4988 stepper controllers (already have them on hand) instead of the DRV8825s? If so what changes do I need to make in the firmware?  Any disadvantage/advantage using the A4988s? Thanks
comments.author: nexgen91

comments.text: Maybe. You could be drawing too much current with the motors being wired in parallel. The DRV8825s are high current drivers. I think Allted selected these because he planned to wire the motors in parallel. If you want to use A4988s, maybe look at the Black version of those drivers. They're supposed to have about 20% more capacity in output current than the standard A4988.
comments.author: nexgen91

comments.text: I'm thinking of doing a kind of virtual build of this in Solidworks. Reason being, I'm seeing more and more that people want some kind of guid to building this, and as assembly view complete with all hardware could aid in this (and possible be used to make a manual is someone know how to do that part)  So, I was wondering which program was use to draw these parts, and if the original files for the current parts could be uploaded or uploaded in  .STEP or .X_T, to help..... save me some time in redrawing them?
comments.author: DavesMODs

comments.text: You can assemble STL's.
comments.author: DavesMODs

comments.text: I can, however in Solidworks .STL imports look like a hybrid mesh/part, meaning the mesh points are all visible. This is a  negative in three ways; 1- Slows the program as it is tracking each point or each part. 2-The assembly commands such as concentric and Tangent rely on "smooth" circles and surfaces to properly define them (a circle of triangle faces can't be defined as circular). The third is just a visual preference.  Hybrid parts view is not as visually appealing as a true part in renders due to the mesh overlay. So for example, the product image above looks great, but add the mesh over to each part imported from STL and it quickly loosed the visual appeal and clarity of a solid/flat surface looking object.
comments.author: Allted

comments.text:
Hi man! That's a piece of work!
Congrats for your high designing skills.
Just a tough. In the Roller fixing nuts for the Roller_lock, I've intended I should use M4 bolts that uses M4 nuts. Is that ok? I ask just because I found nut pocket at 8mm, while Intl metrics for M4 is 7mm. Even squares nuts won't fit anymore in there.
Hope you'll understand my point. It's almost impossible to find M4 nut at 8mm here.
Anyway, gr8 job.
comments.author: biomushroom

comments.text: If you can get the nuts in there you can use any size you want. I know M3.5 aren't as common but they should fit.
comments.author: biomushroom

comments.text:
Nope... you didn't get it... the pocket is bigger than it should. It should be an M4 -> 7mm, instead it carries the 8mm hex that is for the M5 nut. Just take a look in Google "M4 metric nut size" -> http://image.slidesharecdn.com/dimensionsofmetrichexnuts-121221090634-phpapp01/95/dimensions-of-metric-hex-nuts-1-638.jpg?cb=1356080846
I get your point, but if you want to put your design publicly available in Europe, you should follow IE metric rules.
I know drawing in other measurement system is a pain in the neck, but ask and listen to "metric peoples" helps a lot :)
I managed to correct the design in Inventor and, if you want, I'll post the STL for anyone to use and abuse it.
Cheers my friend.
comments.author: Allted

comments.text: A few things. This is world wide not just Europe. It was designed in the US and does fit the most inexpensive hardware here. Being an engineer most of the work I do is in metric. So to solve this problem the easiest way possible I fit the larger nuts and then smaller nuts should be no big deal just find a little something to stick in there to stop them from spinning. This is about a year and a half old now an very few people seem to have an issue with this. Long story short, this size seems to work for the majority.

comments.text:
Hi, I'm just got my 1st 3D printer and am excited about the prospects of building this CNC setup as well as i've wanted one for a long time. I'm primarely a woodworker, but i love creating things. So primarily looking to do routing work in dense hardwoods. But i also have a need to do some aluminum milling. I'd probably build something ~30"x48" to start. But i'm wondering how accurate & rigid is ur current setup for milling stuff like aluminum at those sizes? And would the new 25.4mm(1") version u are working on provide a marked improvement over the 3/4" version for rigidity? I would even consider going stainless at some point but probably not for the 1st version given the added cost as i need to learn on it.
Thanks
And curious to hear what those who have built are achieving w/ a mostly stock built unit.
comments.author: jjman6

comments.text: Large wood projects and aluminum milling are on two opposite ends of the CNC spectrum. I don't think I would try to do both with the same machine.
comments.author: jjman6

comments.text: Hmm.  Well space a big factor atm as i really don't have the room for 2 machines, let alone 1.  My shop is already full of at least 2 or 3 of every machine.  lol.   3/4" emt is only $3.61 here atm.  While 1" emt is $6.66.   So 1" doesn't offer any more rigidity over 3/4"?  I'm no engineer but seems the added surface would increase it somewhat.  I haven't sourced stainless locally. but i know its expensive online.  I have worked w/ emt b4 and 1" seems stronger then 3/4".
comments.author: Allted

comments.text: 1"emt will not work. You need to verify the OD's. EMT is rated by the ID.
comments.author: jjman6

comments.text: Depends on how much power you want/need. The Proxxon is listed as 100W. That's about a 1/2 amp by my calculations. You might look at trim routers or other rotary tools by Bosch, Ryobi, Porter-Cable, Makita, etc. with 3 amps or more of power. I plan on using a 3.5A/420W (@ 110v US) cutout tool from Harbor Freight (a cheap tool store with most goods from China) that I picked up for less than $20US. You can check eBay or places and look for used tools elsewhere. You may have to design a tool mount, but that should not be too hard--or ask for help.

comments.author: DavesMODs

comments.text:
Thank you, much appreciated.
I was thinking it would work like this (but not quite there printing wise to test), Putting the spring above the nut in the holder (closest the Z motor). Thread the rod upward through the bottom nut and spring until it just touches the second nut. From there, back the rod out 3-4 turns, pushing it up against the second nut (to add downwards tension), and then threading it up all the way to the motor.
I should have everything printed to test in 2-3 days, and let you know how it worked.

comments.text:
Can i use DC PWM speed controller to control the 300 watt spindle? link to the speed controller is given in the link below
http://goo.gl/wpKSKs
comments.author: Allted

comments.text: Yes, you can, but it does add more complexity to your setup.  If you're unsure of the wiring it really is easier to just go with a DW660 and speed controller or DWP611 with built in speed controller - you probably don't want to jump right into spindle control right off the bat if you have no experience with it.  Take it one step at a time, build it, learn the machine, learn the software, learn things using an easy tool like the DW660 - then go for a DC spindle down the road if you want.
comments.author: ishaan

comments.text: Rotary encoders are ideal, self correcting is awesome. Downside is they are usually really expensive. There is a user that used the MPCNC and made his own arduino based rotary encoders. There is a video on you tube.

comments.text: Huge power difference between the micro servos and the Nema 17 steppers.

comments.text: There isn't an issue with a different rates of shrinkage between PETG and PLA?

comments.text: Shrinkage isn't really an issue for either, and they are basically interchangeable in that regard. Everything I have printed with both has been dimensionally the same.
comments.author: GeoDude

comments.text: My MPCNC is 90% PETG, only because I ran out of black PETG and had to print corner blocks in black ABS. I had no problems with shrinkage.
comments.author: GeoDude

comments.text: I made the decision to build this. I have started printing parts. I have 2 additional questions. 1) would black iron pipe work better than conduit since it is much stronger? 2) Are there any parts that could really benefit from being made in aluminum instead of printed? I have a casting setup at home. Once I have everything built and working, I am going to try my hand at lost PLA Casting. I am not sure if this project would have much benefit from aluminum or not.
comments.author: john2364

comments.text: 1) If it is more rigid along it's length, maybe. It is much heavier and the surface finish is questionable. Careful with the work stronger, it doesn't mean much. Ideal is rigid along it length, minimal sag. Light, able to handle high point load on it's surface. Nice surface finish.
comments.author: john2364

comments.text: That makes sense. Yep. strength is vague. I believe that it is more ridged than conduit but I could be wrong. It would be much heavier and I can see your point there. Also, I am not sure about the surface. Black iron pipe is not sand cast so it probably has a good surface. I could see corrosion screwing that up though where conduit is going to be more corrosion resistant.
comments.author: Allted

comments.text: I am thinking about building this but I am concerned about its aluminum capabilities. I have read that aluminum is really its upper limit. I would be interested in this primarily for aluminum with other materials being secondary. Most of the aluminum that I would consider would be sheet and plate so not really thick (probably no more than 1/4".
comments.author: john2364

comments.text:
What limits the use of aluminum is mainly the spindle HP and less so the motor torque. I would suggest using the NEMA 23s to negate that issue. Then you will need to find a more powerful spindle. I would suggest going for a full spindle assembly rather than running a hand spindle like the Dwalt used. These spindles are designed to go through aluminum more easily, and with the better HP, they will have the power to do it. Hope this helps.
Byron
comments.author: john2364

comments.text: It does help, thanks. Nema 23's are not too expensive. I also have a reasonably powerful wood working router that would probably do better than the dewalt. I could also look into a different spindle if that is too big. So that solves the spindle and axis power issue with out much added cost.
comments.author: bhameline

comments.text: I would say it is a rigidity issue. I have never stalled either my steppers or my router, which was a dremel at first. If you plan on doing a lot of aluminum just build it as small and as short as possible. My first 2 videos on you tube were with a tiny flex shaft grinder and tiny 42 oz/in steppers. and as you can see it milled them just fine at a foot print of 30x30.
comments.author: john2364

How much should I scale up the parts for? because the ABS shrinks a little!
comments.author: Mackan108

comments.text: Mine is ABS and I have no problems. It was a bit tight on assembly but it works great. With PLA I was concerned about plastic creep under stress causing looseness over time since studies have shown this in the medical field. Mine was assembled over 9 months ago and used a lot with no loosening of anything. ABS is much more resistant to creep under stress.
comments.author: Mackan108

comments.text: I printed in ABS at scale and no problem.
comments.author: Mackan108

comments.text: I printed it in ABS and didn't scale anything. The only things that were real tight was the bore for the 608 bearing in the Z motor mount, the Z nut holder and the coupling. That being said, the only reason I used ABS is because that's what I had.
comments.author: Mackan108

comments.text: Lots of people have tried it, very few have had success. Printed ABS does not shrink uniformly, so you will get bad parts, especially on the middle assembly.

Great design and execution I am only critical of one small thing, the tool mount is simple but restrictive and I do not like the idea of removing and remounting for different tools plus came up very tight using 8mm Leadscrew with Flanged Nuts.
My solution which is rough to say the least is to have a quick release mount so I can have many different tools attached to back plates with plugs so that moving from Print Head to Milling Head or Laser Head etc would be as simple as
1) Unplug electrical
2) Slide out current head
3) Slide in new Head
4) Plug in electrical
5) Check calibration and continue to etch print engrave or mill as required.
My design is basic but should work but if a standard quick release were available then mounts could be designed onto the stock back plate and shared very simply and quickly.
I am proficient in Many programming languages from COBOL to Visual Studio but do not have time to learn CAD tio the extent I would like at this time so use simple tools like tinkercad to produce prototypes when playing. My attempt is here but if someone with CAD experience produced a standard unit I would prefer to use that.
I have posted my attempt on here as an example rather than for people to use.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1156014

comments.text: For printing big, consider the E3D V6 Volcano. It has a different heatbreak/nozzle with larger volume hot end and was designed for extruding high plastic volume fast. It was designed for printing very large parts. You will probably need a geared extruder too. You can find an eBay clone cheap and with a couple of hours of prep work (polishing barrel, seasoning, etc)  it should work fine.

comments.text: Did anyone use petg to print the parts?
comments.author: Scenz

comments.text:
PETG is now my goto plastic for mechanical assemblies. I started out with PLA and some ABS but after I got a spool of PETG from the Microcenter I printed the rest of the Z assembly in it including Allted's newer Middle_Z_rigid, all of Camar0's Rigid_Middle_Z assembly and my Makita tool holder. PETG has excellent interlayer bonding, has the flexibility of ABS and does not have the brittleness of PLA. It warps less than ABS but I did have had one part pop off the build plate due to insufficient contact area. I suggest an 80C build plate, Aquanet hairspray and a 4mm brim. Also a bit of aluminum foil can help to keep the chamber warmer depending on your printer. I did some destructive testing of some PLA and PETG parts and the PETG was much stronger. It interestingly does not break apart on layer boundaries but seems to tear apart randomly. PETG does string a lot so you need to keep your nozzle clean or it will accumulate globs of black plastic. All my parts were printed with 0.3mm layers on a Kickstarter Robo3D.
-SteveC
comments.author: Scenz

comments.text: How stiff was the PETG after you printed it?  I'm not sure if it will be rigid enough.  My taz 5 warps ABS like it's going out of style and PLA doesn't work for crap in it.

comments.author: mogey336

comments.text:
I think that one small change needs to be made in the Marlin firmware to get a PWM TTL signal out to control the laser. The RAMPS's unused printer fan PWM output pin is used to control the On/Off state and intensity of the laser though the laser's "TTL" input. The default for the fan pin is a transistor driving 12V between connector P3 and P4. This needs to be switched in the firmware to a TTL output like D4 on the SERVO 4 connector. Changing the motherboard #define in the Configuration.h file to this should remap the fan output to the SERVO 4 connector:
"#define MOTHERBOARD BOARD_RAMPS_13_EEB"
Note that I have not tried this yet. Others please chime in if other changes are needed or I messed this up.
comments.author: mogey336

comments.text: I am not much of a complainer but something really made me upset. The USB cable you supplied with your kit seems to be faulty. I used it with one of my laptops using the CNC, which worked great, and every time I plugged in the usb cable my touchpad would stop working so I had to unplug it every time I wanted to move my mouse, and I really didn't think anything bad at the time. About a week later after doing several different jobs on my CNC my computer wouldn't recognize an arduino anymore, none of my arduinos worked with the computer and the computer was using the neccessary driver files. After the next few weeks I used the same cable to program my other arduinos and the arduinos didn't do what my programs specified, so I looked over the program several times and couldn't find an error. I even did a simple program like digitalwrite one port HIGH and wait 2 seconds and turn it off and wait 10 seconds. It seems that the HIGH/LOW is swapped that it turns on a digital port when it is in LOW and turns it off when it is HIGH. I thought that it was the computer I was using so I did the same thing on another computer with a different arduino that didnt have that problem and it did the SAME thing. I even tried a different usb cable and it did the same thing. I then realized that it had to be the USB cable ruining my arduinos and my computers usb ports since it wont even recognize a usb flashdrive anymore. I had 5 working arduinos and it ruined 4. They still work if I use HIGH for off and LOW for on but do this weird sequence first when the arduino starts up randomly changing the values of the digital ports every second for about 5 seconds and then it stops. I ruined one of my arduino nanos by plugging it in to the computer that had the faulty usb ports(big mistake) then I realized that it didn't work anymore. I am wondering if one of the 5 volt wires are touching the data cable sending 5 volts to my arduino and sending 5 volts to the computer(which has a protection against that but after a few hours of the cable being connected to the computer it ruined it, knowing that the protection can only protect it for so long until it's dead. I am not 100% positive this is the issue, It could just be an compatiblility issue between the computer and the arduino, but I dont think this is true because I used a different arduino and a different computer and the same cable and it had the same exact problem. I am really upset about this.
comments.author: Justin1

comments.text:
I'm sorry you are having these issues. I don't test every cable anymore because I have never found a bad one. I do use them throughout the batch to program with and switch every 5 boards or so. These have actually outlasted the other cables I used to use that were longer. I have never heard of an arduino failing with reverse logic. You could do a quick continuity check to see if it is actually the cable.
You said this one worked initially? Even If I had tested that cable it would have worked fine then, I don't know how else I can test them. I use these cables myself and trust them.
I am sorry this happened to you, what do you think I should I do to make this right?
comments.author: Justin1

comments.text: I had this same problem before but it ended up ruining the entire arduino board. I put power in the voltage input pin on the arduino while having it connected to my computer so 2 different power being put into the board ruined it (it started smoking around the usb connector on the arduino). I noticed that you have the power supply powering the arduino board and it is required to plug in the usb cable to your computer so additional power is being put on the board. Maybe seperating the power of the ramps board and the arduino or just putting cables in the kits that have the ground and the data wire without the +5v wire. I could be wrong, the arduino may be able to support voltage input and usb input at the same time but I am just telling from my own experience. I did use a voltage meter on the cable and found that 2 of the conductors had high resistance to eachother telling me that 2 of the conductors are in partial contact. I also did the same thing to a cable that worked and it didnt have any reading at all telling me that the cable is truely defective. I believe that the cable was either defective when I got it or was fine when I got it and through hours of use with 2 different ways of powering the arduino board were on it could have partially melted the conductors in the usb cable and caused a connection. I understand that you don't manufacture the cables nor do you have time to examine every cable you have, but I write this to tell you "Hey, something went wrong". I don't care about the the usb ports on my computer since it is owned by my school so they will have to fix it but I am still really upset about my arduinos being bad.
comments.author: Allted

comments.text:
I pre wire the power supply so you can not plug it into the wrong port. That power absolutely has to be there for the system to run. I am doing nothing different from any other 3D printer on the market. If you are having power issues you should look into a lcd screen add on. It would be the safe option for you.
The power to the ramps is separate from the arduino, is it possible you set the board on a conductive surface?
As far as I know usb needs all 4 wires, and your computer should have overload protection. I have programmed literally thousands of ramps kits through my laptop at a previous job and have never fried a usb port. Please understand there is a possibility that this is not my fault.
A resistance test is not the same as a continuity test high resistance could mean a bad connection, has nothing to do with a short.
Every wire should have resistance.
comments.author: Justin1

comments.text: I understand that there isn't anything you did wrong. What I was saying was there wasn't a bad connection that 2 seperate conductors inside the cable were in partial contact causing some resistance between 2 seperate wires. What I mean by resistance is the resistance reading from my voltage meter. I used the resistance tester on my voltage meter instead of the continuity tester since I have a cheap voltage meter and the continuity tester doesn't work well and sometimes doesn't work at all. There shouldn't be any resistance reading on my voltage meter between the 2 seperate wires. I know that my voltage meter isn't giving a false reading because I have tested another cable that works just fine and it didn't show anything at all. I really believe this to be a defective cable. I understand that my computer has an overload protection but after several hours of being plugged in it could fail. Also, would you know of the brand that makes your usb cables, it would be very much appriciated.
comments.author: Allted

comments.text:
Justin1
Arduinos have notoriously flimsy 5V regulators that converts the voltage delivered by the Ramps board. You probably did no ruined the whole arduino, just the 5V regulator on the Arduino board (this is a very common issue). On my prusa I just disconnected the diode on the Ramps board that supplies the input voltage to the Arduino 5V regulator and powered the Arduino with an External 5V supply (via spliced USB cable). Some people did creative soldering of a more capable 5V regulator on the Arduino board. Also, if the resettable 5V fuse on the Arduino board is shorted at any point in time it may never recover to a low resistance state (hence underpowering the Arduino). Good news is, if you separate the 5V supply as I describe above you can resuscitate the "ruined" boards (i.e. if the problem was just the regulator of fuse).
comments.author: Justin1

comments.text: In my experience this usually this means the 5 volt regulator on the Mega 2560 is blown. I have blown a couple before. The regulators can be replaced if you are handy with a soldering iron. Look here: http://www.instructables.com/id/Fix-a-fried-Arduino-Mega/

comments.author: Jimmystanley37

comments.text: Just to be clear on the LCD types. The smaller one also has a much bigger version called the XXL LCD. They have 4 lines of text and use the exact same firmware change in "configuration.h". The other is called the Full Graphics LCD and requires a different change in "configuration.h". I have the XXL on my printer and it is really nice. I have the Full Graphics one on my MPCNC and it works well but I think the display is kind of busy with a lot of unnecessary graphics. I have not used a dedicated PC for my printer or CNC in ages. The SD card is a more reliable and simpler way to feed the gcode.

comments.text: Has anyone tried using the Rumba board with the mostly printed CNC?  I think it might be able to give us a 2nd stepper driver for each of our 2 motors that are currently sharing a single stepper driver.  Even with 5 drivers for the CNC (2X, 2Y, 1Z stepper drivers) it still has an E2 left for an extruder if we want to print or you could possibly use it to add a 4th axis.  Even for the people using NEMA 17 this would double the X,Y torque back to its rated levels per motor.  Also the motors would each be directly wired into the board which would be slightly simpler.  It's $50 on eBay but it does come with the Arduino built in.  I am not familiar with how to enable or pair the E0, E1, or E2 to another axis though which is why I am asking.
comments.author: Camar0

I have the mostly of materials and the last is print! :-D Have any one print in PETG? I think is bether than PLA in this project, I am right?
comments.author: dinovl

comments.text:
I used PETG from the Microcenter for a Makita mount and the corner block top clamps. It works really well at 0.3mm/layer. Much stronger and more flexible than PLA. It will not delaminate at all and will crack randomly through the layers before it delaminates. It does not warp anywhere nearly as bad as ABS. It can warp a bit and pop off the build plate depending on the part geometry and plate contact area. I suggest Aquanet type hairspray on a cold bed then heated to 80C for printing. For temperamental geometries I use a brim and aluminum foil loosely on the open sides of the printer to keep in the heat.
SteveC
comments.author: dinovl

comments.text: Petg is awesome! Sometimes you get minor curling, but its easy to look out for.

comments.text: I realise this would require quite a redesign, but would there be any advantages in going with square tubing instead of round when it comes to rigidity/stability? I was thinking about using square tubes rotated at a 45 degree angle with bearings running on three or all four sides. Eccentric spacers can then be used to "snug-fit" the carriages.
comments.author: tarjeik

comments.text:
4 bearings at each point instead of 3. 8-10 eccentric expensive spacers. Mostly cost and no wants to adjust a bunch of eccentricthey are built in with the flex of plastic. Round is more rigid than square, think roll cages.
2x4's and vgooves wouldn't be an ideal replacement.
Larger builds is a relative term here. Comparing prive vs volume we are doing quite well as is.
comments.author: tarjeik

comments.text: I'm driving right now so there isn't much I can do to help you. It's very easy to find out what two wires are a pair for your stepper. Just touch two of them together and turn the shaft if it got harder to turn it's a pair. That would mean the other two are a pair. If it didn't get harder to turn then it is not a pair try two others. You can always google finding stepper pairs. There is nothing you can do to regular steppers other than unplugging them while the power is on. Feel free to try any combination and tell it works.

comments.text: What would be a sign that rigidness is starting to become an issue? How would one tell?
comments.author: Humanisticnick

comments.text: I haven't built mine yet, so I'm speculating, but I would imagine you would have uneven cutting depth. As the weight of the spindle and Z axis are pulled by gravity, the X and Y tubing would flex. This would make a "flat" cut into a concave cut. I have been thinking of how to prevent such an issue, and I think quikrete poured into the X and Y axis tubes would be a good way to reinforce the tubes to prevent a great deal of bending. Of course the whole device would gain a lot of weight, but that additional pressure would only be on the legs, and not on any moving parts. Alternatively you could add supports that would not interfere with the rolling of the X and Y motors at required intervals, but personally I think that would take a lot more engineering than just reinforcing the pipe from the inside.
comments.author: Humanisticnick

comments.text:
The z direction has 2 tubes supporting it. I think the bigger concern would be the bit wandering in the X and/or Y direction which only has 1 support in the center, possibly even making the bit not perpendicular to the work surface as well.
This might all not really be an issue, I need to big an overly large one and test it. If you just slow down your cut it should stay pretty true. At some point of course it will be too big. I really think that is somewhere around the 6' mark on both axis for wood, although if you were using this to carve a surfboard in HD foam it would be much larger before you get flex issues, then it would be a oscillation issue before a flex issue, same as with metal 2.5' is probably the limit.
Concrete would probably work just fine, but there is a better way.
I made this for "desktop" CNC'ing. Probably kicks butt up the 4', four foot! Look at any other system out there and check the price vs. size, vs versatility. I feel this is in a separate class.
If you want something huge, the answer is simple, larger diameter tubes. I really didn't think many people would want such a large machine, so I kept it small. I can scale this up, it takes a few days but I am considering it. I have no use or space for such a large machine but it would be cool to see someone tearing through a full sheet of MDF. As soon as I move I'll try it out and see where the issues pop up.
comments.author: psyberjock

comments.text: That's a good question about pausing and tool changes. I was wondering how that would happen as well. I would imagine it would need to travel to the side a bit and then return to home to continue, but what if you tragically move the position while cranking away on the spindle? How would you go about ensuring a proper realignment? I guess if the spindle could be set to a constant home and a temporary home, you could change tools at the constant home and then ask it to go back to the temporary home where the material you're working with is fastened to your table. Maybe this is how it already works on most CNCs, and possibly even this one. I'm still new and haven't gotten mine built yet, if anyone knows the answer to this question I would love to hear it.
comments.author: jlonomo

comments.text:
Typically you pause, move the head, change the tool, then home it so it knows where its at. This requires endstops, and a Z touch off so you know how long the new tool is. Touch offs are easy to make wire a small sheet of metal with a know thickness into the z endstop and the other endstop wire and aligator clip gets attached to the bit. You touch z home with the offset alread in the control software, remove the aligator clip, hit resume.
For this home is best to be the bed surface not the top of the work surface, and should be far enough away from the material that it won't hit during home.

comments.text: Bed leveling.  My bed has been level enough for normal size prints. If not there are three ways. 1. Mill the whole bed flat, pretty easy to do.  2. Add an adjustable plate, like most 3D printers.  3.add an endstop and do software leveling.
comments.author: Jimmystanley37

comments.text: An even easier mod is to pick up an HC-05 bluetooth module, just need a couple resistors to divide the voltage and set up ramps to work over bluetooth, then you can user your android phone or tablet to completely print from it wireless with the GCode Printer app. You can print with bluetooth from your PC too, but it's kinda nice to use an old phone or tablet.
comments.author: Atomist

comments.text:
It was a recent hackaday post: http://hackaday.com/2015/08/20/hello-ramps-meet-esp8266/
I haven't printed anything yet with the MP CNC (to see how the the electronics behaves and the print turns out after hundreds of Gcode lines sent) but I just finished a small laser job via wifi without any problems. For me this mod was worth it, alone for the remote jog functions. The ESP8266 is a pretty fast chip and there's not that much code running on it. It should be quite stable, since there's no complex operating system running around it. Let's see... Bluetooth is an option by the way and even easier to set up...

comments.author: ZeidAmfi

comments.text: The threaded rod is used by 3d-printers the same way. For example M8 rises 1,25 per revolution. The inch rod has almost the same values i think. Stepper does 200 full steps per revolution. So 1,25 / 200 is equal 0,00625mm and this is without microstepping. I would answer your question with YES ;)

comments.text: Will painting the conduit affect the motion? Also, will 1" conduit work?
comments.author: quillford

comments.text: Painting the Conduit is going to add a thin layer to the diameter of the pipe. Say if 3/4" conduit fits snugly through the bearings on the carriage blocks, paint may jam the system because of the added diameter. Spray paint might work because the added diameter will be negligible.
comments.author: quillford

comments.text: The pressure from the bearings will wear the paint off in little racing stripes, I was told even colored anodized wouldn't work. Paint isn't the best idea, polished is the right direction. But who knows, it might and it could be cool, try it on something easy to replace like an outside rail.

comments.text: The motors need to be wired in parallel BUT you need to mirror the wiring on one motor of each pair. That way one motor of that axis will spin clockwise and the other counter clockwise when told to move. Otherwise (if truly parallel) they end up moving opposite and not going anywhere.

comments.text: So here is the deal. For the steppers you hardly need any power at all. The only time 24V helps is with things that get hot.....or straight to a spindle, but ramps 1.4 doesn't like that much power. Well let me clarify, My bundle comes with enough belt and wire to do 48" of axis travel (24x24", 12x36". ect.). So to go to 3.5 you would need to get some extra belt and wire, But smaller is more rigid. All depends on what you're cutting. comments.author: galaxius

comments.text:
Tricky question. Originally I wanted to try out the 32nd stepping that's it.
Then I realized they run cooler, much cooler than my Robo's a4988's for the same current. Doesn't hurt that math for setting the pots is easier.
Then....I read this article and figured out why the math is easier, consistent manufacturing and resistor use.
http://reprap.org/wiki/A4988_vs_DRV8825_Chinese_Stepper_Driver_Boards
comments.author: galaxius

comments.text: Thanks for the link, very informative. I didn't even realise trimpot adjustment was a thing. 1/32 micro stepping and his experience with the DRV8825 drivers is making me think I should also upgrade my Robo3D. Yet another thing for the to-do list.

comments.text: did any one try to make a pcb with this cnc?
comments.author: GolanHertz

comments.text: I've built a Solsylva 10x9 CNC router to mill PCBs a couple of years ago but it can be a disappointing experience. Cutting with V-bits is dependent on a perfectly level work surface and you'll eat through bits. In the end I built a laser engraver, 3dpburner found here on thingiverse to be exact. You can google and find a method where you spray the PCB with black paint and laser engrave the board layout. The laser will remove the paint (etch resist) then a couple of minutes in the acid batch and you're all set. I still use my CNC router to drill the PCB holes and mill the cutouts but I do all my traces and layouts with the laser. Quick and easy. Allted's machine looks very capable for this with a laser diode add-on. I think the Jtech photonics web site has some good info on the PCB laser method.
comments.author: GolanHertz

comments.text: Sounds much better than the milling. We all like lasers. The little video I did you could see how hard it was just to get that tiny test cut level. I could not imagine a 3x3 inch board with a V bit. If I milled a pcb it would be with an endmill until I got a laser because the laser sounds much much easier and I'm sure a much better result.

comments.text: Yes.No worry about burrs causing shorts and no fiberglass dust in the air. Lasers are cool:)

comments.text: I've been printing all of the parts needed for the build and I would just like to know how many hours I can except it will take to print all of them. I've got one roller done but it took 8 hours at 75% infill. Layer height .2 mil. Does this seem long?
comments.author: Ottawa123

comments.text: I kept track of the print data time & weights in an excel spreadsheet.The bearing parts took a total of 41 hours 45 minutes and weighed 28.6oz for all of these. Non bearing parts took 17 hours & 30 minutes & they weighed 21.4oz.  The extra parts I printed took 34 hours & 53 minutes.  My total overall print time was 118 hours & 9 minutes & total overall weight of printed parts was 64.6oz.  I did change the part for the roller mount with wire covers a little.  I printed at the recommended settings of .75 infill for bearing & .5 infill for non bearing in PLA, but did print the Mechanical belt tighteners in PETG.
comments.author: Ottawa123

comments.text: I printed everything at 0.3mm. 0.2 is not necessary for any of the parts and wastes time. Thicker layers can also be stronger. 8 hours seems really excessive. I also have a V5 E3D extruder of my Robo3D.

comments.text:
I've started a build. Just printed the corner parts. I was wondering about the router motor, i don't have any CNC experience before, but, I have used both a dremel as a router and a 2.5 hsp router on oak, and the dremel just doesn't have the power. I had to pucsh harder with the dremel, but, the full size router cuts like going through butter. So, would using a more powerful router head make it easier to cut? On another site the person i asked told me that the higher torque of a more powerful motor would cause problems twisting the gantry. And, that person said the weight would be too much. I've ordered 84oz torque Nema 17's hope that won't be a problem, but I was thinking I would have more power that way, and have ordered the 16 teeth pulleys. (also ordered the drv8825 drivers).
I see that Harbor Freight has a cutting tool rated at 3.5 amp and 28,000 rpm only $20, I might give it a try, but, would have to design a mount for it. (I do lots of 3d part designs)
Allted, you mentioned in a post a possible upgrade design using 2 pipes on the x, y, did you get anywhere with that?
I plan to make this 3x3 on the first build, hopefully if we can go with 2 pipes on the x, y and a center support along the outer rails, then maybe i can go even bigger in the future?
comments.author: unltd108

comments.text: I use a 1/4 HP flex shaft grinder, similar to a foredom. It seems to work well. I have a video of it handling some red oak. Lots of reasons I chose the spindle that I did. comments.text: 2 things: 1) The corner conduit clamps should be redesigned to provide screws for all 4 corners as it is not possible to tighten the 2 that are there 'enough' to completely eliminate 'creep' caused by the tensioned GT-belts pulling them together, and 2) Please add a bit more (1/8-3/16") plastic on the edges of the Z-Axis nutlock so we can actually use 6-32 screws to mount it.  For the 1st issue, while redesign is being planned... here is what I did:   I measured corner-Block end to corner_Block end on all 4 corners, making 3x sure that the lengths of opposite sides were exactly the same, AND the whole frame was square... then with everything including the conduit centered and clamped down in the clamps, I drilled a 5/64ths hole down thru the center of the arch and into the top of the conduit and then dropped a tiny 1" long screw (from a VCR Cassette case) in. Screws are indestructible and  just long enough to penetrate the top of the conduit to keep it from shifting. Result, nothing gets out of 'square' anymore (those belts are constantly pulling at the end blocks and getting your machine out of alignment) 2nd result is the caps now can be 'snug' and don't need to be so tightened down that they blow out or split or break your Corner_Block Locks  :-)  For the second issue, I just used smaller/thinner screws with large (Pop-Rivet) washers and lockwashers on both sides. Now, WHERE is my Z-Axis NEMA 17?

comments.text: Hello, i couldn't tell if this was asked or not, but what size are the metal poles that you used in your make, also i am new to 3D printing, is it possible to implement your design using a screw and nut on all three axis? thank you all for your help.
comments.author: tmd1990

comments.text: You could use lead screws and anti backlash nuts if you have that kind of spare money laying around. Any particular reason you would want to do this over 2 belts?
comments.author: tmd1990

comments.text:
I just thought that it would be more precise and able to withstand heavier loads. Again this is the first machine I have ever built, if belts are a better decision please let me know why,
Thanks
comments.author: Allted

comments.text:
I decided to use belts on my machine because of price vs. performance. You should try the machine as is before you solve problems that might not exist. This has been asked a few times in the comments and emails. It would have to be a different design to use lead screws, which are very expensive, and the anti backlash nuts cost even more. Then you have to tune it for speed range you'll use, and support the lead screws so they don't sag and whip. Think about Harley belt drive motorcycle, 1300cc motor 1 belt. Belts are extremely efficient. If you think the belts are lacking just buy wider ones, as for being precise, it's more of a speed vs precision thing.
Keep it cheap and fun, if you break something while learning, super cheap to replace. If you outgrow this machine your next step is a tormach for $8000+ then its just a mill. I feel it very capable and there is so much to learn. lots of settings to tweak, usually all involving how nice you want the finished part to look vs how long you are willing to wait for it to finish.
comments.author: tmd1990

comments.text: Quick and dirty answers, I'm at work....
comments.author: Cymple

comments.text:
Super quick response man, thanks.
My only experince is my prusa i3 and the stuff i learn in engineering school :D
Wanted to stay with Nema 17 because they are cheaper and since theres two per axis I think I would be fine. The problem that I see is that the stepper drivers on the ramps only go up to like 2.5A with active cooling and thats being split between the two motors in parallel. So even a short nema 17 is not even close to max rating. As far as I know they are rated for 2a for the small ones. Voltage doesnt affect these Motors very much its just an attempt to keep amperage down and maybe gain a little speed and its not more work if I use external drivers anyways...
I thought that I could avoid the heat problem by mounting the plasma tip some distance below the carriage since leverage isnt a problem with non-contact-cutting. Also most plasma torches only have metal at the very tip and a plastic handle so maybe that is not even necessary. Also water table should help there. Hopefully I can solve that problem as it comes along.

comments.text: @Allted, the DRV8825 Vref setting you mention will only drive each paralleled X or Y stepper to 0.582A. That seems a bit low to me. What are the specs for your steppers? My 480mNm NEMA 17s will take 1.5A at 3V per coil so I set Vref to 1V to give 1A to each coil of each XY stepper. The steppers barely get warm and the driver only gets slightly hot. With Vref set closer to .6V the torq seems a bit iffy to me. Perhaps it is my steppers.
comments.author: Director

comments.text:
Kickstarter Robo!...50/50 chance I had some contact with it, hope its still going strong. I still prefer those drawer sliders and that hot end.
So that vref was for 42oz/in 17's (I need to clarify that). That's what I milled the aluminum with in the video. The specs you gave are a bit non standard (.4N-m?). Ideal is put a fan on the ramps (I happen to know a guy that made a fan bracket for the robo), and turn the drivers up to half the amp spec for your stepper/per stepper so the z would be at 50% amp in volts, and the x and y would get vref set to amp rating. Details on the pololu site. Does that make sense? If your amp rating was 1.2 amps z would get set to .6v and x and y to 1.2. drv8825 math is easy. If you turn them above .75v you need a heat sink, much past that you need active cooling.
If you give the model number to you steppers I can take a look.
comments.author: Director

comments.text: Yes my stepper is 0.48Nm = 68oz/in so only a bit stronger than yours. I use the standard DRV8825 heat sink and will put a fan on the RAMPS. comments.author: Allted

comments.text:
What steppers are you using? 1.8 degree or .9 degree, how many teeth on your pulley, what kind of lead screw.
When you say move 100mm how far does it move? Is your voltage set appropriately for your Steppers?
comments.author: bhameline

comments.text: I figured it out. For the TinyG, the input setting is mm/rev, not step/mm. The means all you have to do is take your tooth count and multiply it by your belt pitch. So 16 teeth * 2mm pitch worked out. I am not sure about the Z though. I believe it is 1.4111 for the 5/16-18 because that is the pitch. I believe it is right. I can send anyone my TinyG configuration if they need.
comments.author: Allted

comments.text: Great...was hoping there was some sort of tensionin "system" in place...the more simple the better!  I'm printing mine out of abs. If I had to print new parts here and there it's kind of expected when using printed parts.  Thanks again!
comments.author: JimmyBuckets

comments.text: Looks great! Going to make one.  But is there any adjustments to tighten the rollers...aka eccentric bearings?
comments.author: JimmyBuckets

comments.text: Not really, and hopefully not needed. The bearing parts are all tensioned with what I call the middle bearing, the one that has plastic on both sides of the bearing. Start with that one a bit loose and tighten if needed. Really though, plastic has a "plastic" zone before permanent deformation sets in. Hopefully these all stay nice and snug because of that. over a long period of time or high heat creep may start to loosen thing up a bit. Really though you should get plenty of time before you need to print a few new parts. Mine has been up for 4 months and has no signs of wiggle room. worse case another $10 but in plastic to replace a few bearing blocks after maybe a year, not bad.
comments.author: JimmyBuckets

comments.text: Definately take Allted's advice on this. I found that regular Home Depot or Lowes zinc coated EMT conduit is very rigid at 24". I think that it may need support if you go over 3'. Gas pipe will not be as straight and is less rigid.

comments.text: I started with a 2' x 2' and used conduit. the gas pipe I found was less rigid, less smooth, cost more. You could have found something different. Give them both a shot, the pipe is the cheapest part. Remember each part is supported by 2 pipes, x, y, gantry, and z.

comments.text: Thank you for an excellent idea, and design.  I am sourcing the parts in Norway, and found that 25mm conduit is not hard to find.  One tip: Use steel conduits for the non-moving parts.  They are heavier, making the whole machine less likely to move, and also a lot cheaper than the aluminium conduits.. I use alu conduits for the two moving axis to minimize weight of course.  Planning to build a 1200 x 600 work surface printer, so we'll se if the conduits will be stiff enough to work with such a large span..  (they should, as I am using 3,5mm thick alu counduits).
comments.author: dexus

comments.text: More important than weight is rigidity. Some of the heavy pipes actually flex way more. Conduit is very rigid, I'm guessing it has to do with how the form it must be different from gas pipe. Doesn't really matter what you use as long as it is soft like copper. go to the store and actually flex the pipes before you buy them. You might be surprised at how flexible some of the heavy pipes are.
comments.author: dexus

comments.text: Taking your comments into account, I (rather nervously) checked the rigidity of the steel conduits I bought, and luckily, they are even more rigid than the aluminium conduits.. So I should be fine.. My ultimate goal is to try scaling this up to a full 2400x1220mm  work surface, to be able to work with industrial standard sheets of plywood etc.

comments.text: I would double check those with some calipers. The conduit I use here is sold by the Inside Diameter.  So your 20mm might be the right stuff. comments.text: Mine has heat shrink on all the connections so they are not visible. I can post a wiring diagram at another time.
comments.author: bhameline

comments.text: I don't have a problem with the motors not moving. The problem is that a properly amped motor will run with a singing tone to it, while an over amped motor will sound like its going over a gravel road. An under amped wont move. No mater how low i dropped the amp controllers, I could not get the motors to stop roughing. I'm using a TinyG v8 straight out of the box run through chilipeppr. 24v power supply 15A 360w, no issues there. A single motor works great, but when I reverse the wiring (clockwise A1 A2 B1 B2, counter clockwise B2 B1 A2 A1 so that A1 and B2 go into the same A1 port and A2 and B1 go into the same A2 port) they will both rough at anything above maybe 400 mm/min. My single motors could run at up to 1000 mm/min until they roughed.
comments.author: Allted

comments.text: Did you get them working? Want to share the solution with the other TinyG users?
comments.author: bhameline

comments.text: It should be a1 a2 b1 b2, and in the same order a1 a2 b2 b1

25mm pipe should work fine. Keep things relatively loose during assembly, and tighten it up if needed.

I would stick with the 17's they seem to be doing great.

You zip tie loops at the end of the belt, the teeth side together. Make it just short of the zip tie holes. Then you can use the zip ties to attach the belt to the block and use these for tension as well. You don't need to make the belt super tight. Start snug and only tighten if needed.

description.text:
This is still a work in progress but the MakerBot actually seems to print braille rather well. I can't read braille so I can't judge for sure whether it's readable but it certainly seems like it. The trick is to get the G-code right to prevent warts on the front face (i'm still fiddling with this).
I think this might have a lot of potential. A braille bracelet will be next in my printing/designing queue.

I downloaded a braille front from http://www.softpedia.com/get/Others/Font-Utils/Braille-3D.shtml. Then I just extruded it and put it against a flat surface. I printed it in the vertical direction because I thought that would give me the best resolution without having little strands connecting everything but it may be worth a shot to try it flat.

author: atb485

title: Spulenhalter MKIII für RepRapPro Ormerod /  spool mount MKIII for RepRapPro Ormerod

description.text:
Spulenhalter fuer RepRapPro Ormerod Drucker Zur Befestigung des Halters werden 2 Zylinderkopfschrauben + Unterlegscheiben benötigt.
(Diese ersetzen die original Senkkopfschrauben) Dieser Halter lässt sich für viele derzeit gebräuchliche Spulen nutzen.
Im Gegensatz zum Vorgängermodell können Spulen hier auch horizontal befestigt werden.
(Ein entsprechender Adapter folgt) Die Anbauteile die für das Vorgängermodell konstruiert wurden passen auch an diese Ausführung.
Bei den Befestigungsbohrungen auf der Schmalseite ist zu beachten, das diese nicht mit allen
Anbauteilen und nicht unbedingt gleichzeitig mit den Befestigungsbohrungen auf den
Längsseiten genutzt werden können. Zusätzlich zu den oben genannten Befestigungsschrauben wird mindestens noch eine M8 Gewindestange plus Muttern
als Achse für die Spulen benötigt. Am effizientesten funktioniert das System in Verbindung mit den passenden Spulenadaptern.
(Ebenfalls auf thingiverse zu finden) Alles weitere ist eigentlich selbsterklärend und kann den Bildern entnommen werden. Update: 06.04.2015
Der weiter oben angekündigte Adapter für die horizontale Spulenlagerung ist jetzt ebenfalls verfügbar.
(Falls ich irgendwann herausfinde wie ich hier einen Link einfüge, mach ich das dann noch :-)....) Update: 19.04.2015
Erstellung einer neuen Version / Variante
Spulenhalter MKIII_S (short)
Hierbei handelt es sich um eine kürzere Version!
Diese Version ist 20mm kürzer (niedriger) als die Normalversion, damit lässt sich das Teil auch auf vielen Ormerod-Druckern erstellen bei denen das Druckbett modifiziert wurde.
(Oft geht bei der Veränderung etwas Bauraumhöhe verloren) Durch die Verkürzung fällt die oberste Aufnahme für die Spulenachse weg, das sollte in der Praxis aber nicht zu sehr ins Gewicht fallen.

Die Aufnahmen für die Achsen müssen nach dem Druck eventuell mit einem 8mm Bohrer
nachbearbeitet werden.
Beim Druck unbedingt darauf achten, das die einzelnen Layer später nicht delaminieren!
(Nicht zu "kalt" drucken)

title: Parametric Traxxas 5347 ball joint to carbon fiber rod connector for delta printers

description.text:
A parametric Traxxas 5347 ball joint to carbon fiber rod connector for delta printers.  
This is a simple part that I designed to connect carbon fiber rods / tubes to Traxxas 5347 ball joints, with a minimum amount of material and minimum weight.  
Uses epoxy glue to glue the CF rod and the Traxxas ball joint.  
OpenSCAD source included so it can be further remixed. License is GPLV3.
Printed in PLA with 35% infill, sliced with Cura.

build_plate_selector = 0
pattern_radius = 5
iphone_version = 1
pattern_shape = 7
pattern_rotation = 84

I wanted a spool holder that mounted on the top of my TAZ 4 without hardware of any type, so I threw this together. It's more solid than it needs to be, but it snaps into place on the 20mm extrusions and works beautifully. Uses a 3/4" dowel that just drops in. I'd like to integrate some 608ZZ bearings, but
a) I was itching to get this made and didn't have any on hand, and
b) I'm concerned that the lack of friction will facilitate spool unraveling - probably not worth worrying about.

I printed it out of PLA with support, then measured and cut a piece of 3/4" diameter oak dowel for the shaft.  I think it was 120mm, but measure the required distance before you cut.  
Let me know if you have any ideas for improvements!

title: Replacement retainer for Tag Heuer rubber strap

description.text:
I had my original retainers broken four times in the last two years.
Tag does not sell these retainers separately - you are required to buy an entirely new rubber band. Therefore I decided to design and print one myself.
This one fits perfectly on my Formula One original rubber strap.
I hope you find it useful.

Print it using .200mm layer height.
If you use ABS, I suggest heating your bed to 90 degrees celsius to avoid warping.

description.text: wall right http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:713210

A simple case for our AllPixel LED controller board . Comes with two variants for the top, one with and one without a hole for the optional 1000uF capacitor. Small hole in the top is for pressing the reset button with a paperclip.

Print with 0.2mm layer height and supports enabled when printing the top. After printing, lay a piece of 200+ grit sandpaper on a flat, hard surface and sand down the top of the bottom piece and the bottom of the top piece, so that the two pieces will fit together flush. You will need two M4-0.7 pan-head screws, between 6 and 10mm in length to secure to to sides together.
Sign for EyeTV video at Eyer Middle School.

remixed_from.author: Moidules
remixed_from.title: Moidules - Create your own custom made shelving system at home!

description.text:
I like this project and people have asked for a customizer version. Since the creator mentioned he has no experience using openSCAD or customizer (neither do i), I thought I'd help out by either making all the parts or at least making one example the creator can run with to make the remaining parts. Either way, I found this little exercise fun since I;m a programmer by trade.  
The only issue I'm having is that the M does not seem to show up in customizer nor when creating a custom stl. BUT it does appear in OpenSCAD where I wrote the code. So i have no clue why its not working in customizer, if anyone has an answer to that, I'll apply the fix and reupload.  
Side note, I added screw holes to the X part, if you put the size of zero, it will not be added to the part.

description.text:
This is part of a project I was required to complete in order to graduate senior year of high school. To accompany a toy tractor and lowboy set, I created a skeleton of a Styracosaurus. My mentor helped me laser cut the individual pieces that I drew up on Autodesk Inventor.
Number of pieces to complete the build: (29)
1x Mane
1x Backbone
2x Face plates
8x Ribs (A-H)
1x Front Hip & Back Hip
2x Front Legs
2x Hind Legs
2x Hip Bones
9x Tail Bones Note: When laser cutting these pieces, I had to remove and replace all the splines in the ribs and backbone with arcs in order for the program to show all the lines of each piece.
I've uploaded all of the Inventor files and STL files for anyone's use. If there are any discrepancies, please comment!

Mount Fuji constructed using 1 arcsecond resolution SRTM data from the Space Shuttle (about 1.9 million polygons). It was made using a new and, as yet, unreleased version of SRTM2STL. The source code for creating files at 3 arcsecond resolution is available up on github under the GNU license. Go to github and search for SRTM2STL.

You may want to print this to be relatively small. I used to get warping using PLA and it got bad when I try to print Raised Relief Maps that are big. Now that I have a heated bed, I get much better results.

comments.text: Thanks for the comment! When I was play testing the first design of this with the group I play with they made the same comment, but after a game everyone liked how the life is displayed so you don't have to look over it to see it and its viewable from anywhere on the table including where you are sitting. If you look at the pictures I posted with this design, the one that shows my general, the dice are displaying a life total of 40 or 4 and 20 depending on how you view your dice. description.text:
Camera mount for Raspberry Pi Camera on a Vertex K8400 printer. New version 2 added. In version 1 it turned out that the friction around the ball lost the grip after some time using PLA. Therefore I created version 2 which include a bolt in each joint so the friction can be tightened in case it starts loosing the grip.
Also added a split part so I can use two base parts to fasten in the Vertex frame, it makes the camera more stable.

Sharps Container:  A simple box  with only a slit opening for disposing of sharp blades (like x-acto) safely.

Best to print on it's side (narrowest) so there's shortest bridge distance.
The slit for inserting blades is curved, and there are "lips" on the inner aspect (see wireframe drawing), but the features are too small to print when printed at "medium" resolution.

A clever tree tap that lets you screw a water bottle on! Fresh maple sap is actually quite delicious, especially if you add a little bit of lemon juice. Put the bottle on at the beginning of the day, and enjoy some sap later.  
Notes: Tree tapping is usually done in very early spring, when the trees are just thawing.   
This design also incorporates thing:35907.

You will need:
  • Some Epoxy
  • A Plastic Bottle
    • Instructions:
  • Print both parts without support. Print the tap with a brim, or else it will probably fall over during the print.
  • Mix up some epoxy and glue the cap to the hole on the tap. Make sure you let it dry for a bit.
  • Drill a hole in a maple tree with a 15/32 inch or 12mm bit, about 5 or 6 cm deep.
  • Push the assembled tap in, wait until some sap starts coming out. It could take a couple minutes.
    5.Screw the bottle on and enjoy!

author: Damage

title: Yet another modular loc-line cooling hose for 3D printer

description.text: An OpenSCAD variation on the loc-line cooling hose, usable as cooling for a 3D printer. It seems to work better than other cooling variants I've tested, and allows adjustments of the cooling end, which is so hard to get perfect otherwise. Depending on your 3D printer settings, you might need different "size offsets" between the hole and the round part (in my STLs set to 0.2mm, which seems to work with my printer). If thats the case, just use the SCAD file instead of the STLs, and change top_diff_size value.
