description.text:
Shamrock Keyring for St Partick's Day! (National Holiday - Ireland)
Inspired by Orbit Love Charm by CDavis, but redrawn from scratch in 123D Design. Bevels added to edges for nice finish. It prints pre-assembled and the center swivels around when done. 123D Design file also shared should you want to examine or modify the design.

Slice the STL and print.
.2mm height works well.
Printing 50/50 in two shades of green, then flipping the center piece over gives a nice effect.
With a direct drive printer like the Mendel90 it's possible to cut the filament closely to the drive, when the print is roughly half done, then feed a different colour (different share of green in this case) without stopping the print. Once you thread the new filament into the extruder hole, catch the filament away from the extruder (about 10cm above or so) allowing it to flex but still applying pressure until the hobbed bolt picks up the new filament. Stay clear of fast moving parts.

title: Printrbot Simple (Metal) Ubis Dual Bowden Extruder Attachment

description.text: Modified version, can hold two Ubis extruders for dual extrusion.

Remove the existing aluminium extruder and replace it with this model.   
put the ubis extruder in it from below, secure it with two screws. if your extruder doesnt fit (because the holes are a lil bit bigger) just use some tape and wrap it around the extruder.  
Screw a push-fitting on top of it and you've got an simple bowden extruder.   
Use a RAMPS board or the Extrudrboard for a secondary stepper controller, wire it, set the distance to Y+26mm. make sure both extruders are on the same Z height and enjoy the dual head printing.

description.text: 86 Standard back box 1 gang slim

A printed version of a brass slide rule (that I keep in my car to calculate gas mileage) I made previously.  I'm having trouble coming up with a good way to join them.  Ideally, I'd like the joining to be done with one piece that still allows for a hole in the middle, like with the brass version, but I didn't like any of the ideas I came up with.  Please help / derive.  
Update: I came up with a center piece that I'm happy with.  As I am currently CAD-less, my friend J. Ferrari did the CAD work for the center piece.

The center piece is bent to fit in the center hole.  The ends of that piece won't bend as easily by themselves, so I had to bend them a little with pliers.  Also, it's designed to be printed with 0.25 mm layers.

comments.text: If you do that, then you're printing with support which won't leave a smooth surface and the pieces won't slide as well together.  I also don't like having a lip that protrudes in the Z direction.  If it's thin enough to snap together, it'll be likely to break along a layer boundary.  But if you can come up with a good way to do it, I'd love to see it.

description.text:
This is a model of a Traxxas rod end, with a swiveling spherical ball insert. It gets screwed onto the ends of tie rods to allow an adjustable mechanical link between two points, often times with a servo at one end. The bore accepts a 3mm screw or tie rod. The bearing end also accepts a 3mm screw or bolt. It is a model of:
Traxxas part # 2742X It is actually two separate pieces with .003" clearance between the ball and housing at 1-1 scaling. This gap is purposely more than the real one would have in hopes it might be an actual printable working bearing with the right settings/scaling.

title: D-Link DCS Series IP Camera Mount

description.text:
This is a camera mount for a D-Link DCS IP cameras. I designed it for the Flashforge Creator Pro / Powerspec Pro but it may also work for other similar printers. There are some other nice designs already out there but I decided to create this one primarily so that I could make it more compact, have easier access to the build chamber, and open and close the door without effecting the camera position. Designed to work on either the top left or right corner and firmly fixed to prevent any bouncing or rotation. Uses existing machine screws - no additional hardware required. **NOTE: Version 2 added with the following improvements:
  • Moved camera further over to prevent obstruction with door
  • Added chamfer to bracket corner for additional support
Printed with ABS at 0.1mm resolution.

This is my 737 throttle quadrant for a flight simulator. The dimensions should all be fairly accurate. The throttle levers to go with it can be found at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:725595. I haven't got around to uploading the other levers yet. More info in the Instructions bit, and at http://cockpitonabudget.wordpress.com (I'm still working on the wordpress, don't be too harsh)

I didn't actually 3D print this - I was going to, but then my printer died :(. Instead I split it up into roughly 30 individual 2D panels then cut it all out of MDF, then glued it all together. If you'd like these panels, just leave a comment or something and I'll send them.
I then made the flaps, cutout and speed brake out of aluminium bar, and just bent it. For flaps, also made a small box with a spring making it need to be pulled up for it to be moveable. It doesn't look great but then nobody will ever see it. There's a picture above. Throttle were 3 flat panels of 6mm MDF, the centre hollowed and microswitches installed (for reversers.) The actual handle bit I turned on a lathe but it would be much better printing it. If you plan to make this, you'll need a few things:
• roughly 5 microswitches (reversers and park brake)
• 6 potentiometers (levers)
• 1 red LED (park brake)
• 2 toggle switches (Stab trim)
• bolts + screws
• 5 push buttons (TOGA, AT off, horn cutout)
• a spring (for flaps. ideally there would also be springs on speed brake lever, cutout levers and the reversers. If you aren't going to print much and are doing most of it by hand like me, you'll need
• drill (cordless is best)
• bolts/nuts/screws + screwdrivers/spanners/pliers etc
• lots of MDF of varying widths
• lots of PVA glue
• a jigsaw or bandsaw to cut out the panels (bandsaw's best)
• a sander to get them all accurate (electric!)
• polyfilla to make it all nice and smooth
• aluminium bar
• araldite or other really strong glue (for the aluminium bar)
• a router's can be useful, otherwise a wood file should do the job
• a hacksaw for cutting bolts, etc
• and a 3D printer for when you decide that you can't be bothered. It does take a while. And to make it much, much easier for you, don't glue it all together until the handles and levers are in. I've got more detail at http://cockpitonabudget.wordpress.com. I am still working on that site though, so don't be too harsh.

title: Daily earring #60: Small combination lock / Enhanced Cryptex
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
-More DailyEarrings & prologue @ thingiverse.com/thing:7120 This morning I saw http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7233 (inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4414) and within an hour (while watching TV) I made this small combination lock as AE's daily earring number sixtey (yey!). This simplified little combination lock is just a bit taller then one centimeter and could probably be made even smaller. It actually worked on the first print, just had to reprint for some cosmetics reasonst and longer lock bars to lessen the play. This one opens with A / E and has a few letters on each ring. Excuse the bad pictures, I had to use the flash and then harsh gamma correction so the details show- resulting in an odd look. IMPORTAINT!
Printed on a pp3dp up + on 0.2mm/fine; You will need angled tweezers to clean out some of the support, but it was easier then I thought. The bars on the innter tubus are just a bit too long, you may want to sand them, clip them, cut them etc.
CHANGES:
On the new version I alreaddy made them 0.3mm shorter- but not thiner.
Made the top disc flat for easier holding while turning, but the faces are not closed properly.

Designed for a pp3dp UP+, perhaps you will need to enlarge it and resize the gaps/play; Source files included. Possible fixing issues/changes: -Fix some minor offset and loose issues/play
-Inner gaps not neccesary
-A front marker to indicate where you have to turn the letters to.
-A bit bigger hole to store secret messages in the tube
-inner tubus lock-bars are a tad too long (can be sanded/cut, but on the new version I alreaddy made them 0.3mm shorter- but not thiner)
-Also helps to make them a little thinner
-The inner "rails" are unneccesary, but won't hurt anything.
-The gap/rail in the rings need to be scraped thinner a bit where they end in the opening to ensure it turns well This version works, but needs some work to move freely. Feel free to change the files.

base_radius_add = 3

It's a Mag-Lifter! Which I guess... is pretty much a forklift? That uses magnets? Which makes it all future-ey? Well, anyway, here it is, and it all fits together without glue or whatever. The grabbers can move left and right, and go up and down as well. It's sized for Pocket-Tactics scale models, and a standard human-sized model will inside pretty snugly. If you want this in 28mm scale, I would advise scaling it up by about 165%. I haven't tried it yet, but let me know if you do. Enjoy! -Models shown are from the United Separatist Militia Pocket-Tactics set: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:607453
